Main-usage-of-harmonizR

2023-03-17

Source: vignettes/Main-usage-of-harmonizR.Rmd
Main-usage-of-harmonizR.Rmd

Introduction

This vignette is a first step into the harmonizR to facilitate the data harmonization process. The package follows Maelstrom Research approach and standards. It is built on madshapR and fabR.

For more information about Maelstrom Research, see here.

Bellow is a walkthrough of the harmonization process using the package harmonizR and established harmonization rules. It shows how to:

  • Explore datasets prior to harmonization
  • Generate bookdown reports of study-specific variables
  • Read and interpret the data processing elements (harmonization potential and data processing rules) to generate harmonized dataset(s)
  • Generate bookdown reports of harmonized variables

Please note that all the demo files mentioned below are downloadable on an Opal demo environment.

Get started

To download our package, you need to have an account on GitHub and create a secure key (in the format “ghp_xxx”).

You can send us your Github name using the following link so we can add you to our authorized list of users.

# To update the R package in your R environment you may first need to remove it, 
# and use the exit command quit() to terminate the current R session.

# To install the R package:
devtools::install_github(
  repo = "https://github.com/maelstrom-research/harmonizR",
  auth_token = "ghp_YouNeedaValidGithubTOKEN!!!",
  force = TRUE)
library(harmonizR)
library(madshapR)
library(fabR)

#if you need help with the package, please use:
harmonizR_help()

Demonstration files

The madshapR library contains demonstration files useful to try harmonizR.


names(DEMO_files)

# To see examples:
DEMO_files[1] #Data processing elements
DEMO_files[4] #Dataschema 
DEMO_files[5] #Data dictionaries
DEMO_files[15] #Datasets

Harmonize

harmonizR requires specific inputs to achieve the harmonization process, and includes many validation of the inputs provided.

The general process involves to:

  • Prepare the datasets and inputs
  • Associate dataset(s) and their data dictionary (facultative)
  • Group dataset(s) in a study object
  • Harmonize a study using the data schema and data processing element
  • Review the harmonized study

When you have no errors, this is straigthforward. The first step is to prepare the datasets in a study:

# Associate metadata from data dictionnary to the the data
dataset_MELBOURNE_1 <- data_dict_apply(data = DEMO_files$dataset_MELBOURNE_1,
                                       data_dict = DEMO_files$dd_MELBOURNE_1_format_maelstrom)
dataset_MELBOURNE_2 <- data_dict_apply(data = DEMO_files$dataset_MELBOURNE_2,
                                       data_dict = DEMO_files$dd_MELBOURNE_2_format_maelstrom)
dataset_PARIS <- data_dict_apply(data = DEMO_files$dataset_PARIS,
                                 data_dict = DEMO_files$dd_PARIS_format_maelstrom)
dataset_TOKYO <- data_dict_apply(data = DEMO_files$dataset_TOKYO,
                                 data_dict = DEMO_files$dd_TOKYO_format_maelstrom_tagged)


# group the datasets in a study object
# NB: the name of the datasets in the study must match the column ss_table in the data processing element
study_ALL <- study_create(list(dataset_MELBOURNE_1, dataset_MELBOURNE_2, dataset_PARIS, dataset_TOKYO))

Then you can proceed with the harmonization:

# Harmonization process
harmonized_ALL <- harmo_process(study = study_ALL,
                                dataschema = DEMO_files$DEMO_dataschema,
                                data_procelem = DEMO_files$`data_processing_elements - final`)

And finally assess your harmonized data:

# Assess the harmonization
harmonized_ALL_eval <- harmonized_study_evaluate(harmonized_ALL)
harmonized_ALL_eval$`Mlstr::pooled_harmonized_dataset` #identify errors and potential issues

# Produce summary statistics of the harmonized data
harmonized_ALL_summary <- harmonized_study_summarise(harmonized_ALL)
write_excel_allsheets(harmonized_ALL_summary$`Mlstr::pooled_harmonized_dataset`,
                      filename = "DEMO/harmonized_summary.xls") # Save summary as Excel if needed

# Generate visual report
harmonized_study_visualize(harmonized_ALL, to="DEMO/visual_harmonized")
open_visual_report("DEMO/visual_harmonized") # open the report in browser

Identify errors and explore inputs

The harmonizR package also includes functions coming from madshapR to validate the data and inputs required for the harmonization. Functions ending by “_evaluate” identify errors [ERR] and warn of potential issues [INFO]. Functions ending by “_summary” produce descriptive statistics of the data. Visualization of the distribution of the data can also be produced using “_visualize” functions.

Data dictionnaries:

data_dict_evaluate(DEMO_files$`dd_TOKYO_format_maelstrom_tagged - ERROR WITH DATA`)

data_dict_evaluate(DEMO_files$`dd_TOKYO_format_maelstrom_tagged - ERROR`)

data_dict_evaluate(DEMO_files$dd_TOKYO_format_maelstrom_tagged)

Datasets:

# Create a dataset with errors
dataset_TOKYO_errors <- data_dict_apply(data = DEMO_files$`dataset_TOKYO - ERROR WITH DATA`,
                                        data_dict = DEMO_files$`dd_TOKYO_format_maelstrom_tagged - ERROR WITH DATA`)

# Evaluate the dataset
dataset_evaluate(dataset = dataset_TOKYO_errors)


# Generate a summary and save as Excel file
TOKYO_summary <- dataset_summarize(dataset = dataset_TOKYO_errors)
write_excel_allsheets(TOKYO_summary,
                      filename = "DEMO/TOKYO_summary.xls")

# Generate a visual report
dataset_visualize(dataset = dataset_TOKYO_errors,
                  to = "DEMO/visual_dataset_TOKYO_errors")
open_visual_report("DEMO/visual_dataset_TOKYO_errors")

Studies:

# Create study with errors
study_ERRORS <- study_ALL
study_ERRORS$dataset_TOKYO <- dataset_TOKYO_errors

# Evaluate the study
study_evaluate(study_ERRORS)

# Generate a summary for each datasets in the study
study_ERRORS_summary <- study_summarize(study_ERRORS)
write_excel_allsheets(TOKYO_summary,
                      filename = "DEMO/study_ERRORS_summary.xls")

Data schemas:

dataschema_evaluate(DEMO_files$`dataschema - final`)

Errors in harmonization

When there are issues in the harmonization, the process is interrupted and a tibble of errors is produced instead.

# Harmonization with errors in data processing elements
harmonized_ERRORS <- harmo_process(study = study_ALL,
                                dataschema = DEMO_files$`dataschema - final`,
                                data_procelem = DEMO_files$`data_processing_elements - with error`)
# Show errors
harmonized_ERRORS
show_harmo_error(harmonized_ERRORS)
